author: sameelaughs
content: Volumnia Cytheris, also known as Lycoris in Gallus' poetry, had *relations* with Brutus, Mark Antony, and many famous men. Her rejection of Cornelius Gallus is recorded in Vergil's 10th eclogue. Cicero disliked her, saying he was ashamed to go to the same party as her-- Meanwhile, Cicero's wife, Terentia, asked Cytheris for help to fix the relationship between her husband and Cytheris' lover (Mark Antony)... Unfortunately, she was not succesful

author: sameelaughs
content: Valens was not very great at reading long sourcebooks. Thus, he asked Eutropius, his secretary and magister memoriae to write him a *Brevarium ab Urbe Condita*, a shortened version of Livy's book among other sources like Suetonius. However, even this was not enough for Valens, and Rufius Festius had to write, supposedly low quality, *one book summary* of roman history, focusing on Roman conquests that led to the creation of the Empire.

content: Rutilius Rufus was exiled to Asia because he was wrongly convicted in the extortion court, despite trying to stop extortion. At his place of exile, in Smyrna, he lived as ‚Äúan honoured citizen among the provincials he was alleged to have oppressed‚Äù, was heavily praised by Vellius Paterculus, and visited by Cicero. Sulla asked him to come back, but Rutilius Rufus said he didn‚Äôt want to leave his ‚Äòexile‚Äô.

author: sameelaughs
content: Ennius‚Äô legacy survives through a decapitated statue marked ‚ÄúQ. Ennius‚Äù. Cicero writes that Ennius wrote an epigram commemorating the statue: ‚Äúaspicite, o cives, senis Enni imaginis formam. / Hic vestrum pinxit maxima facta patrum.‚Äù Ennius also wrote an epitaph for his tomb: ‚Äúnemo me lacrimis decoert nec funera fletu / faxit, cur? volito vivus per ora vivum‚Äù.

author: sameelaughs
content: Ennius frequently uses literary devices in his *Annales*, such as tmesis (*saxo cere corrupuit brum*, "he split his br apart ain with a rock"), alliteration (*o Tite Tute tibi tanta tyranne tulisti*, "O Titus Tatius, you brought such great things to yourself, tyrant"), and onomatopoeia (at tuba terribili sonituo taratantara dixit, "But the trumpet with its terrible sound said 'taratantara'" ).

author: sameelaughs
content: Ennius called himself ‚Äúdicti studiosus‚Äù, meaning he was the first Latin poet on par with the Greek and Alexandrine poets.

author: sameelaughs
content: The commentator Servius wrote on Vergil‚Äôs description of Romulus and Remus, saying ‚Äúsane totus hic locus Ennianus est‚Äù.

author: sameelaughs
content: Ennius himself wrote ‚Äúnumquam poetor nisi si podager‚Äù (I never poetize unless I have the gout).

author: sameelaughs
content:
Juvenal's biting Satire 6 is 661 lines
- longest and most famous of Juvenal‚Äôs satires
- attacks women; refers to a good woman as a ‚Äúrara avis‚Äù
- addresses a man who is delusional enough to think about getting married
- proposes suicide as a much less painful alternative to marriage
- claims that Chastity abandoned the Earth at the conclusion of the Golden Age
- claims that most all women are unfaithful, relentlessly seek abortions, murder their stepchildren, and use potions that drive their husbands insane
- contains the line ‚Äúquis custodiet ipsos custodes‚Äù
- overall wtf moment

author: sameelaughs
content: In 80, probably commissioned by figures in the court, Martial published a collection of epigrams celebrating the inauguration of the Flavian Amphitheater, which resulted in Titus rewarding him with appreciation, monetary support, and the ius trium liberorum, a right later confirmed by Domitian.

author: sameelaughs
content: In 98, Martial left Rome for good on a voyage to Bilbilis paid for by Pliny the Younger. Martial, living on an estate given to him by a lady named Marcella, he continued to be unhappy until he died at Bilbilis ~104.

author: sameelaughs
content: In 87-88, Martial became so annoyed by city life that he spent time in Forum Corneli (modern Imola) and other cities in the region of Emilia, but shortly returned to Rome.

author: sameelaughs
content: Within Martial's poetry,in the Epigrammata, he claims his auctores were Catullus, Domitius Marsus, Albinovanus Pedo, and Lentulus Gaetulicus.

author: sameelaughs

author: sameelaughs
content: After the collapse of the Pisonian conspiracy caused the ruins of the Senecas and Pisos in 65, Martial lost most of his income, but maintained his property at Nomentum, 13 miles from Rome, given to him by Seneca the Younger

author: sameelaughs
content: Sallust was expelled from the Senate by the censor Appius for 'moral aptitude', but then this was explained as him sleeping with Fausta, the wife of Annius Milo. However, after the end of the civil war, Caesar restored Sallust so quickly that the initial expulsion was probably politically motivated.
